text: After the death of Saul, David returned from striking down the Amalekites and stayed in Ziklag two days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the third day a man arrived from Saul’s camp with his clothes torn and dust on his head. When he came to David, he fell to the ground to pay him honour.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Where have you come from?’ David asked him.
He answered, ‘I have escaped from the Israelite camp.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘What happened?’ David asked. ‘Tell me.’
‘The men fled from the battle,’ he replied. ‘Many of them fell and died. And Saul and his son Jonathan are dead.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said to the young man who brought him the report, ‘How do you know that Saul and his son Jonathan are dead?’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘I happened to be on Mount Gilboa,’ the young man said, ‘and there was Saul, leaning on his spear, with the chariots and their drivers in hot pursuit.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he turned round and saw me, he called out to me, and I said, “What can I do?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘He asked me, “Who are you?”
‘“An Amalekite,” I answered.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Then he said to me, “Stand here by me and kill me! I’m in the throes of death, but I’m still alive.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘So I stood beside him and killed him, because I knew that after he had fallen he could not survive. And I took the crown that was on his head and the band on his arm and have brought them here to my lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David and all the men with him took hold of their clothes and tore them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They mourned and wept and fasted till evening for Saul and his son Jonathan, and for the army of the Lord and for the nation of Israel, because they had fallen by the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
David said to the young man who brought him the report, ‘Where are you from?’
‘I am the son of a foreigner, an Amalekite,’ he answered.
speaker: Narrator

text: David asked him, ‘Why weren’t you afraid to lift your hand to destroy the Lord’s anointed?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David called one of his men and said, ‘Go, strike him down!’ So he struck him down, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: For David had said to him, ‘Your blood be on your own head. Your own mouth testified against you when you said, “I killed the Lord’s anointed.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: David took up this lament concerning Saul and his son Jonathan,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he ordered that the people of Judah be taught this lament of the bow (it is written in the Book of Jashar):
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘A gazelle lies slain on your heights, Israel.
    How the mighty have fallen!
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Tell it not in Gath,
    proclaim it not in the streets of Ashkelon,
lest the daughters of the Philistines be glad,
    lest the daughters of the uncircumcised rejoice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Mountains of Gilboa,
    may you have neither dew nor rain,
    may no showers fall on your terraced fields.
For there the shield of the mighty was despised,
    the shield of Saul – no longer rubbed with oil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘From the blood of the slain,
    from the flesh of the mighty,
the bow of Jonathan did not turn back,
    the sword of Saul did not return unsatisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul and Jonathan –
    in life they were loved and admired,
    and in death they were not parted.
They were swifter than eagles,
    they were stronger than lions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Daughters of Israel,
    weep for Saul,
who clothed you in scarlet and finery,
    who adorned your garments with ornaments of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘How the mighty have fallen in battle!
    Jonathan lies slain on your heights.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I grieve for you, Jonathan my brother;
    you were very dear to me.
Your love for me was wonderful,
    more wonderful than that of women.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘How the mighty have fallen!
    The weapons of war have perished!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the course of time, David enquired of the Lord. ‘Shall I go up to one of the towns of Judah?’ he asked.
The Lord said, ‘Go up.’
David asked, ‘Where shall I go?’
‘To Hebron,’ the Lord answered.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David went up there with his two wives, Ahinoam of Jezreel and Abigail, the widow of Nabal of Carmel.
speaker: Narrator

text: David also took the men who were with him, each with his family, and they settled in Hebron and its towns.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the men of Judah came to Hebron, and there they anointed David king over the tribe of Judah.
When David was told that it was the men from Jabesh Gilead who had buried Saul,
speaker: Narrator

text: he sent messengers to them to say to them, ‘The Lord bless you for showing this kindness to Saul your master by burying him.
speaker: Narrator

text: May the Lord now show you kindness and faithfulness, and I too will show you the same favour because you have done this.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now then, be strong and brave, for Saul your master is dead, and the people of Judah have anointed me king over them.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Abner son of Ner, the commander of Saul’s army, had taken Ish-Bosheth son of Saul and brought him over to Mahanaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made him king over Gilead, Ashuri and Jezreel, and also over Ephraim, Benjamin and all Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ish-Bosheth son of Saul was forty years old when he became king over Israel, and he reigned two years. The tribe of Judah, however, remained loyal to David.
speaker: Narrator

text: The length of time David was king in Hebron over Judah was seven years and six months.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abner son of Ner, together with the men of Ish-Bosheth son of Saul, left Mahanaim and went to Gibeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab son of Zeruiah and David’s men went out and met them at the pool of Gibeon. One group sat down on one side of the pool and one group on the other side.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Abner said to Joab, ‘Let’s have some of the young men get up and fight hand to hand in front of us.’
‘All right, let them do it,’ Joab said.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they stood up and were counted – twelve men for Benjamin and Ish-Bosheth son of Saul, and twelve for David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then each man grabbed his opponent by the head and thrust his dagger into his opponent’s side, and they fell down together. So that place in Gibeon was called Helkath Hazzurim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The battle that day was very fierce, and Abner and the Israelites were defeated by David’s men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The three sons of Zeruiah were there: Joab, Abishai and Asahel. Now Asahel was as fleet-footed as a wild gazelle.
speaker: Narrator

text: He chased Abner, turning neither to the right nor to the left as he pursued him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Abner looked behind him and asked, ‘Is that you, Asahel?’
‘It is,’ he answered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abner said to him, ‘Turn aside to the right or to the left; take on one of the young men and strip him of his weapons.’ But Asahel would not stop chasing him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again Abner warned Asahel, ‘Stop chasing me! Why should I strike you down? How could I look your brother Joab in the face?’
speaker: Narrator

text: But Asahel refused to give up the pursuit; so Abner thrust the butt of his spear into Asahel’s stomach, and the spear came out through his back. He fell there and died on the spot. And every man stopped when he came to the place where Asahel had fallen and died.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joab and Abishai pursued Abner, and as the sun was setting, they came to the hill of Ammah, near Giah on the way to the wasteland of Gibeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men of Benjamin rallied behind Abner. They formed themselves into a group and took their stand on top of a hill.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abner called out to Joab, ‘Must the sword devour for ever? Don’t you realise that this will end in bitterness? How long before you order your men to stop pursuing their fellow Israelites?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab answered, ‘As surely as God lives, if you had not spoken, the men would have continued pursuing them until morning.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joab blew the trumpet, and all the troops came to a halt; they no longer pursued Israel, nor did they fight any more.
speaker: Narrator

text: All that night Abner and his men marched through the Arabah. They crossed the Jordan, continued through the morning hours and came to Mahanaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joab stopped pursuing Abner and assembled the whole army. Besides Asahel, nineteen of David’s men were found missing.
speaker: Narrator

text: But David’s men had killed 360 Benjaminites who were with Abner.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took Asahel and buried him in his father’s tomb at Bethlehem. Then Joab and his men marched all night and arrived at Hebron by daybreak.
speaker: Narrator

text: The war between the house of Saul and the house of David lasted a long time. David grew stronger and stronger, while the house of Saul grew weaker and weaker.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sons were born to David in Hebron:
his firstborn was Amnon the son of Ahinoam of Jezreel;
speaker: Narrator

text:
his second, Kileab the son of Abigail the widow of Nabal of Carmel;
the third, Absalom the son of Maakah daughter of Talmai king of Geshur;
speaker: Narrator

text:
the fourth, Adonijah the son of Haggith;
the fifth, Shephatiah the son of Abital;
speaker: Narrator

text:
and the sixth, Ithream the son of David’s wife Eglah.
These were born to David in Hebron.
speaker: Narrator

text: During the war between the house of Saul and the house of David, Abner had been strengthening his own position in the house of Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Saul had had a concubine named Rizpah daughter of Aiah. And Ish-Bosheth said to Abner, ‘Why did you sleep with my father’s concubine?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Abner was very angry because of what Ish-Bosheth said. So he answered, ‘Am I a dog’s head – on Judah’s side? This very day I am loyal to the house of your father Saul and to his family and friends. I haven’t handed you over to David. Yet now you accuse me of an offence involving this woman!
speaker: Narrator

text: May God deal with Abner, be it ever so severely, if I do not do for David what the Lord promised him on oath
speaker: Narrator

text: and transfer the kingdom from the house of Saul and establish David’s throne over Israel and Judah from Dan to Beersheba.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Ish-Bosheth did not dare to say another word to Abner, because he was afraid of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abner sent messengers on his behalf to say to David, ‘Whose land is it? Make an agreement with me, and I will help you bring all Israel over to you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Good,’ said David. ‘I will make an agreement with you. But I demand one thing of you: do not come into my presence unless you bring Michal daughter of Saul when you come to see me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David sent messengers to Ish-Bosheth son of Saul, demanding, ‘Give me my wife Michal, whom I betrothed to myself for the price of a hundred Philistine foreskins.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ish-Bosheth gave orders and had her taken away from her husband Paltiel son of Laish.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her husband, however, went with her, weeping behind her all the way to Bahurim. Then Abner said to him, ‘Go back home!’ So he went back.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abner conferred with the elders of Israel and said, ‘For some time you have wanted to make David your king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now do it! For the Lord promised David, “By my servant David I will rescue my people Israel from the hand of the Philistines and from the hand of all their enemies.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: Abner also spoke to the Benjaminites in person. Then he went to Hebron to tell David everything that Israel and the whole tribe of Benjamin wanted to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abner, who had twenty men with him, came to David at Hebron, David prepared a feast for him and his men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abner said to David, ‘Let me go at once and assemble all Israel for my lord the king, so that they may make a covenant with you, and that you may rule over all that your heart desires.’ So David sent Abner away, and he went in peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just then David’s men and Joab returned from a raid and brought with them a great deal of plunder. But Abner was no longer with David in Hebron, because David had sent him away, and he had gone in peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joab and all the soldiers with him arrived, he was told that Abner son of Ner had come to the king and that the king had sent him away and that he had gone in peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joab went to the king and said, ‘What have you done? Look, Abner came to you. Why did you let him go? Now he is gone!
speaker: Narrator

text: You know Abner son of Ner; he came to deceive you and observe your movements and find out everything you are doing.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab then left David and sent messengers after Abner, and they brought him back from the cistern at Sirah. But David did not know it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when Abner returned to Hebron, Joab took him aside into an inner chamber, as if to speak with him privately. And there, to avenge the blood of his brother Asahel, Joab stabbed him in the stomach, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, when David heard about this, he said, ‘I and my kingdom are for ever innocent before the Lord concerning the blood of Abner son of Ner.
speaker: Narrator

text: May his blood fall on the head of Joab and on his whole family! May Joab’s family never be without someone who has a running sore or leprosy or who leans on a crutch or who falls by the sword or who lacks food.’
speaker: Narrator

text: (Joab and his brother Abishai murdered Abner because he had killed their brother Asahel in the battle of Gibeon.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said to Joab and all the people with him, ‘Tear your clothes and put on sackcloth and walk in mourning in front of Abner.’ King David himself walked behind the bier.
speaker: Narrator

text: They buried Abner in Hebron, and the king wept aloud at Abner’s tomb. All the people wept also.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king sang this lament for Abner:
‘Should Abner have died as the lawless die?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your hands were not bound,
    your feet were not fettered.
You fell as one falls before the wicked.’
And all the people wept over him again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they all came and urged David to eat something while it was still day; but David took an oath, saying, ‘May God deal with me, be it ever so severely, if I taste bread or anything else before the sun sets!’
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people took note and were pleased; indeed, everything the king did pleased them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So on that day all the people there and all Israel knew that the king had no part in the murder of Abner son of Ner.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king said to his men, ‘Do you not realise that a commander and a great man has fallen in Israel this day?
speaker: Narrator

text: And today, though I am the anointed king, I am weak, and these sons of Zeruiah are too strong for me. May the Lord repay the evildoer according to his evil deeds!’
speaker: Narrator

text: When Ish-Bosheth son of Saul heard that Abner had died in Hebron, he lost courage, and all Israel became alarmed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Saul’s son had two men who were leaders of raiding bands. One was named Baanah and the other Rekab; they were sons of Rimmon the Beerothite from the tribe of Benjamin – Beeroth is considered part of Benjamin,
speaker: Narrator

text: because the people of Beeroth fled to Gittaim and have resided there as foreigners to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Jonathan son of Saul had a son who was lame in both feet. He was five years old when the news about Saul and Jonathan came from Jezreel. His nurse picked him up and fled, but as she hurried to leave, he fell and became disabled. His name was Mephibosheth.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Rekab and Baanah, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, set out for the house of Ish-Bosheth, and they arrived there in the heat of the day while he was taking his noonday rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went into the inner part of the house as if to get some wheat, and they stabbed him in the stomach. Then Rekab and his brother Baanah slipped away.
speaker: Narrator

text: They had gone into the house while he was lying on the bed in his bedroom. After they stabbed and killed him, they cut off his head. Taking it with them, they travelled all night by way of the Arabah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought the head of Ish-Bosheth to David at Hebron and said to the king, ‘Here is the head of Ish-Bosheth son of Saul, your enemy, who tried to kill you. This day the Lord has avenged my lord the king against Saul and his offspring.’
speaker: Narrator

text: David answered Rekab and his brother Baanah, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, ‘As surely as the Lord lives, who has delivered me out of every trouble,
speaker: Narrator

text: when someone told me, “Saul is dead,” and thought he was bringing good news, I seized him and put him to death in Ziklag. That was the reward I gave him for his news!
speaker: Narrator

text: How much more – when wicked men have killed an innocent man in his own house and on his own bed – should I not now demand his blood from your hand and rid the earth of you!’
speaker: Narrator

text: So David gave an order to his men, and they killed them. They cut off their hands and feet and hung the bodies by the pool in Hebron. But they took the head of Ish-Bosheth and buried it in Abner’s tomb at Hebron.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the tribes of Israel came to David at Hebron and said, ‘We are your own flesh and blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the past, while Saul was king over us, you were the one who led Israel on their military campaigns. And the Lord said to you, “You shall shepherd my people Israel, and you shall become their ruler.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the elders of Israel had come to King David at Hebron, the king made a covenant with them at Hebron before the Lord, and they anointed David king over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was thirty years old when he became king, and he reigned for forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: In Hebron he reigned over Judah for seven years and six months, and in Jerusalem he reigned over all Israel and Judah for thirty-three years.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king and his men marched to Jerusalem to attack the Jebusites, who lived there. The Jebusites said to David, ‘You will not get in here; even the blind and the lame can ward you off.’ They thought, ‘David cannot get in here.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, David captured the fortress of Zion – which is the City of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day David had said, ‘Anyone who conquers the Jebusites will have to use the water shaft to reach those “lame and blind” who are David’s enemies.’ That is why they say, ‘The “blind and lame” will not enter the palace.’
speaker: Narrator

text: David then took up residence in the fortress and called it the City of David. He built up the area around it, from the terraces inwards.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he became more and more powerful, because the Lord God Almighty was with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Hiram king of Tyre sent envoys to David, along with cedar logs and carpenters and stonemasons, and they built a palace for David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David knew that the Lord had established him as king over Israel and had exalted his kingdom for the sake of his people Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he left Hebron, David took more concubines and wives in Jerusalem, and more sons and daughters were born to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of the children born to him there: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ibhar, Elishua, Nepheg, Japhia,
speaker: Narrator

text: Elishama, Eliada and Eliphelet.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Philistines heard that David had been anointed king over Israel, they went up in full force to search for him, but David heard about it and went down to the stronghold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Philistines had come and spread out in the Valley of Rephaim;
speaker: Narrator

text:
so David enquired of the Lord, ‘Shall I go and attack the Philistines? Will you deliver them into my hands?’
The Lord answered him, ‘Go, for I will surely deliver the Philistines into your hands.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So David went to Baal Perazim, and there he defeated them. He said, ‘As waters break out, the Lord has broken out against my enemies before me.’ So that place was called Baal Perazim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines abandoned their idols there, and David and his men carried them off.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once more the Philistines came up and spread out in the Valley of Rephaim;
speaker: Narrator

text: so David enquired of the Lord, and he answered, ‘Do not go straight up, but circle round behind them and attack them in front of the poplar trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as you hear the sound of marching in the tops of the poplar trees, move quickly, because that will mean the Lord has gone out in front of you to strike the Philistine army.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So David did as the Lord commanded him, and he struck down the Philistines all the way from Gibeon to Gezer.
speaker: Narrator

text: David again brought together all the able young men of Israel – thirty thousand.
speaker: Narrator

text: He and all his men went to Baalah in Judah to bring up from there the ark of God, which is called by the Name, the name of the Lord Almighty, who is enthroned between the cherubim on the ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: They set the ark of God on a new cart and brought it from the house of Abinadab, which was on the hill. Uzzah and Ahio, sons of Abinadab, were guiding the new cart
speaker: Narrator

text: with the ark of God on it, and Ahio was walking in front of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: David and all Israel were celebrating with all their might before the Lord, with castanets, harps, lyres, tambourines, rattles and cymbals.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to the threshing-floor of Nakon, Uzzah reached out and took hold of the ark of God, because the oxen stumbled.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s anger burned against Uzzah because of his irreverent act; therefore God struck him down, and he died there beside the ark of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David was angry because the Lord’s wrath had broken out against Uzzah, and to this day that place is called Perez Uzzah.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was afraid of the Lord that day and said, ‘How can the ark of the Lord ever come to me?’
speaker: Narrator

text: He was not willing to take the ark of the Lord to be with him in the City of David. Instead, he took it to the house of Obed-Edom the Gittite.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ark of the Lord remained in the house of Obed-Edom the Gittite for three months, and the Lord blessed him and his entire household.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now King David was told, ‘The Lord has blessed the household of Obed-Edom and everything he has, because of the ark of God.’ So David went to bring up the ark of God from the house of Obed-Edom to the City of David with rejoicing.
speaker: Narrator

text: When those who were carrying the ark of the Lord had taken six steps, he sacrificed a bull and a fattened calf.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wearing a linen ephod, David was dancing before the Lord with all his might,
speaker: Narrator

text: while he and all Israel were bringing up the ark of the Lord with shouts and the sound of trumpets.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the ark of the Lord was entering the City of David, Michal daughter of Saul watched from a window. And when she saw King David leaping and dancing before the Lord, she despised him in her heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought the ark of the Lord and set it in its place inside the tent that David had pitched for it, and David sacrificed burnt offerings and fellowship offerings before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he had finished sacrificing the burnt offerings and fellowship offerings, he blessed the people in the name of the Lord Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he gave a loaf of bread, a cake of dates and a cake of raisins to each person in the whole crowd of Israelites, both men and women. And all the people went to their homes.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David returned home to bless his household, Michal daughter of Saul came out to meet him and said, ‘How the king of Israel has distinguished himself today, going around half-naked in full view of the slave girls of his servants as any vulgar fellow would!’
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Michal, ‘It was before the Lord, who chose me rather than your father or anyone from his house when he appointed me ruler over the Lord’s people Israel – I will celebrate before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will become even more undignified than this, and I will be humiliated in my own eyes. But by these slave girls you spoke of, I will be held in honour.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And Michal daughter of Saul had no children to the day of her death.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the king was settled in his palace and the Lord had given him rest from all his enemies around him,
speaker: Narrator

text: he said to Nathan the prophet, ‘Here I am, living in a house of cedar, while the ark of God remains in a tent.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Nathan replied to the king, ‘Whatever you have in mind, go ahead and do it, for the Lord is with you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But that night the word of the Lord came to Nathan, saying:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Go and tell my servant David, “This is what the Lord says: are you the one to build me a house to dwell in?
speaker: Narrator

text: I have not dwelt in a house from the day I brought the Israelites up out of Egypt to this day. I have been moving from place to place with a tent as my dwelling.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherever I have moved with all the Israelites, did I ever say to any of their rulers whom I commanded to shepherd my people Israel, ‘Why have you not built me a house of cedar?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Now then, tell my servant David, “This is what the Lord Almighty says: I took you from the pasture, from tending the flock, and appointed you ruler over my people Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have been with you wherever you have gone, and I have cut off all your enemies from before you. Now I will make your name great, like the names of the greatest men on earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will provide a place for my people Israel and will plant them so that they can have a home of their own and no longer be disturbed. Wicked people shall not oppress them any more, as they did at the beginning
speaker: Narrator

text:
and have done ever since the time I appointed leaders over my people Israel. I will also give you rest from all your enemies.
‘“The Lord declares to you that the Lord himself will establish a house for you:
speaker: Narrator

text: when your days are over and you rest with your ancestors, I will raise up your offspring to succeed you, your own flesh and blood, and I will establish his kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is the one who will build a house for my Name, and I will establish the throne of his kingdom for ever.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will be his father, and he shall be my son. When he does wrong, I will punish him with a rod wielded by men, with floggings inflicted by human hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: But my love will never be taken away from him, as I took it away from Saul, whom I removed from before you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your house and your kingdom shall endure for ever before me; your throne shall be established for ever.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: Nathan reported to David all the words of this entire revelation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then King David went in and sat before the Lord, and he said:
‘Who am I, Sovereign Lord, and what is my family, that you have brought me this far?
speaker: Narrator

text: And as if this were not enough in your sight, Sovereign Lord, you have also spoken about the future of the house of your servant – and this decree, Sovereign Lord, is for a mere human!
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘What more can David say to you? For you know your servant, Sovereign Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the sake of your word and according to your will, you have done this great thing and made it known to your servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘How great you are, Sovereign Lord! There is no one like you, and there is no God but you, as we have heard with our own ears.
speaker: Narrator

text: And who is like your people Israel – the one nation on earth that God went out to redeem as a people for himself, and to make a name for himself, and to perform great and awesome wonders by driving out nations and their gods from before your people, whom you redeemed from Egypt?
speaker: Narrator

text: You have established your people Israel as your very own for ever, and you, Lord, have become their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘And now, Lord God, keep for ever the promise you have made concerning your servant and his house. Do as you promised,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that your name will be great for ever. Then people will say, “The Lord Almighty is God over Israel!” And the house of your servant David will be established in your sight.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Lord Almighty, God of Israel, you have revealed this to your servant, saying, “I will build a house for you.” So your servant has found courage to pray this prayer to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sovereign Lord, you are God! Your covenant is trustworthy, and you have promised these good things to your servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now be pleased to bless the house of your servant, that it may continue for ever in your sight; for you, Sovereign Lord, have spoken, and with your blessing the house of your servant will be blessed for ever.’
speaker: Narrator

text: In the course of time, David defeated the Philistines and subdued them, and he took Metheg Ammah from the control of the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: David also defeated the Moabites. He made them lie down on the ground and measured them off with a length of cord. Every two lengths of them were put to death, and the third length was allowed to live. So the Moabites became subject to David and brought him tribute.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, David defeated Hadadezer son of Rehob, king of Zobah, when he went to restore his monument at the River Euphrates.
speaker: Narrator

text: David captured a thousand of his chariots, seven thousand charioteers and twenty thousand foot soldiers. He hamstrung all but a hundred of the chariot horses.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Arameans of Damascus came to help Hadadezer king of Zobah, David struck down twenty-two thousand of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put garrisons in the Aramean kingdom of Damascus, and the Arameans became subject to him and brought tribute. The Lord gave David victory wherever he went.
speaker: Narrator

text: David took the gold shields that belonged to the officers of Hadadezer and brought them to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Tebah and Berothai, towns that belonged to Hadadezer, King David took a great quantity of bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Tou king of Hamath heard that David had defeated the entire army of Hadadezer,
speaker: Narrator

text: he sent his son Joram to King David to greet him and congratulate him on his victory in battle over Hadadezer, who had been at war with Tou. Joram brought with him articles of silver, of gold and of bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: King David dedicated these articles to the Lord, as he had done with the silver and gold from all the nations he had subdued:
speaker: Narrator

text: Edom and Moab, the Ammonites and the Philistines, and Amalek. He also dedicated the plunder taken from Hadadezer son of Rehob, king of Zobah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And David became famous after he returned from striking down eighteen thousand Edomites in the Valley of Salt.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put garrisons throughout Edom, and all the Edomites became subject to David. The Lord gave David victory wherever he went.
speaker: Narrator

text: David reigned over all Israel, doing what was just and right for all his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab son of Zeruiah was over the army; Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was recorder;
speaker: Narrator

text: Zadok son of Ahitub and Ahimelek son of Abiathar were priests; Seraiah was secretary;
speaker: Narrator

text: Benaiah son of Jehoiada was over the Kerethites and Pelethites; and David’s sons were priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: David asked, ‘Is there anyone still left of the house of Saul to whom I can show kindness for Jonathan’s sake?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now there was a servant of Saul’s household named Ziba. They summoned him to appear before David, and the king said to him, ‘Are you Ziba?’
‘At your service,’ he replied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king asked, ‘Is there no one still alive from the house of Saul to whom I can show God’s kindness?’
Ziba answered the king, ‘There is still a son of Jonathan; he is lame in both feet.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Where is he?’ the king asked.
Ziba answered, ‘He is at the house of Makir son of Ammiel in Lo Debar.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So King David had him brought from Lo Debar, from the house of Makir son of Ammiel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Mephibosheth son of Jonathan, the son of Saul, came to David, he bowed down to pay him honour.
David said, ‘Mephibosheth!’
‘At your service,’ he replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Don’t be afraid,’ David said to him, ‘for I will surely show you kindness for the sake of your father Jonathan. I will restore to you all the land that belonged to your grandfather Saul, and you will always eat at my table.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Mephibosheth bowed down and said, ‘What is your servant, that you should notice a dead dog like me?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king summoned Ziba, Saul’s steward, and said to him, ‘I have given your master’s grandson everything that belonged to Saul and his family.
speaker: Narrator

text: You and your sons and your servants are to farm the land for him and bring in the crops, so that your master’s grandson may be provided for. And Mephibosheth, grandson of your master, will always eat at my table.’ (Now Ziba had fifteen sons and twenty servants.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ziba said to the king, ‘Your servant will do whatever my lord the king commands his servant to do.’ So Mephibosheth ate at David’s table like one of the king’s sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mephibosheth had a young son named Mika, and all the members of Ziba’s household were servants of Mephibosheth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Mephibosheth lived in Jerusalem, because he always ate at the king’s table; he was lame in both feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the course of time, the king of the Ammonites died, and his son Hanun succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text:
David thought, ‘I will show kindness to Hanun son of Nahash, just as his father showed kindness to me.’ So David sent a delegation to express his sympathy to Hanun concerning his father.
When David’s men came to the land of the Ammonites,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Ammonite commanders said to Hanun their lord, ‘Do you think David is honouring your father by sending envoys to you to express sympathy? Hasn’t David sent them to you only to explore the city and spy it out and overthrow it?’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hanun seized David’s envoys, shaved off half of each man’s beard, cut off their garments at the buttocks, and sent them away.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David was told about this, he sent messengers to meet the men, for they were greatly humiliated. The king said, ‘Stay at Jericho till your beards have grown, and then come back.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Ammonites realised that they had become obnoxious to David, they hired twenty thousand Aramean foot soldiers from Beth Rehob and Zobah, as well as the king of Maakah with a thousand men, and also twelve thousand men from Tob.
speaker: Narrator

text: On hearing this, David sent Joab out with the entire army of fighting men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Ammonites came out and drew up in battle formation at the entrance of their city gate, while the Arameans of Zobah and Rehob and the men of Tob and Maakah were by themselves in the open country.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab saw that there were battle lines in front of him and behind him; so he selected some of the best troops in Israel and deployed them against the Arameans.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put the rest of the men under the command of Abishai his brother and deployed them against the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab said, ‘If the Arameans are too strong for me, then you are to come to my rescue; but if the Ammonites are too strong for you, then I will come to rescue you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be strong, and let us fight bravely for our people and the cities of our God. The Lord will do what is good in his sight.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joab and the troops with him advanced to fight the Arameans, and they fled before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Ammonites realised that the Arameans were fleeing, they fled before Abishai and went inside the city. So Joab returned from fighting the Ammonites and came to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the Arameans saw that they had been routed by Israel, they regrouped.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hadadezer had Arameans brought from beyond the River Euphrates; they went to Helam, with Shobak the commander of Hadadezer’s army leading them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David was told of this, he gathered all Israel, crossed the Jordan and went to Helam. The Arameans formed their battle lines to meet David and fought against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they fled before Israel, and David killed seven hundred of their charioteers and forty thousand of their foot soldiers. He also struck down Shobak the commander of their army, and he died there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When all the kings who were vassals of Hadadezer saw that they had been routed by Israel, they made peace with the Israelites and became subject to them.
So the Arameans were afraid to help the Ammonites any more.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the spring, at the time when kings go off to war, David sent Joab out with the king’s men and the whole Israelite army. They destroyed the Ammonites and besieged Rabbah. But David remained in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: One evening David got up from his bed and walked around on the roof of the palace. From the roof he saw a woman washing. The woman was very beautiful,
speaker: Narrator

text: and David sent someone to find out about her. The man said, ‘She is Bathsheba, the daughter of Eliam and the wife of Uriah the Hittite.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David sent messengers to get her. She came to him, and he slept with her. (Now she was purifying herself from her monthly uncleanness.) Then she went back home.
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman conceived and sent word to David, saying, ‘I am pregnant.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So David sent this word to Joab: ‘Send me Uriah the Hittite.’ And Joab sent him to David.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Uriah came to him, David asked him how Joab was, how the soldiers were and how the war was going.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said to Uriah, ‘Go down to your house and wash your feet.’ So Uriah left the palace, and a gift from the king was sent after him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Uriah slept at the entrance to the palace with all his master’s servants and did not go down to his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was told, ‘Uriah did not go home.’ So he asked Uriah, ‘Haven’t you just come from a military campaign? Why didn’t you go home?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Uriah said to David, ‘The ark and Israel and Judah are staying in tents, and my commander Joab and my lord’s men are camped in the open country. How could I go to my house to eat and drink and make love to my wife? As surely as you live, I will not do such a thing!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said to him, ‘Stay here one more day, and tomorrow I will send you back.’ So Uriah remained in Jerusalem that day and the next.
speaker: Narrator

text: At David’s invitation, he ate and drank with him, and David made him drunk. But in the evening Uriah went out to sleep on his mat among his master’s servants; he did not go home.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning David wrote a letter to Joab and sent it with Uriah.
speaker: Narrator

text: In it he wrote, ‘Put Uriah out in front where the fighting is fiercest. Then withdraw from him so that he will be struck down and die.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So while Joab had the city under siege, he put Uriah at a place where he knew the strongest defenders were.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men of the city came out and fought against Joab, some of the men in David’s army fell; moreover, Uriah the Hittite died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab sent David a full account of the battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: He instructed the messenger: ‘When you have finished giving the king this account of the battle,
speaker: Narrator

text: the king’s anger may flare up, and he may ask you, “Why did you get so close to the city to fight? Didn’t you know they would shoot arrows from the wall?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who killed Abimelek son of Jerub-Besheth? Didn’t a woman drop an upper millstone on him from the wall, so that he died in Thebez? Why did you get so close to the wall?” If he asks you this, then say to him, “Moreover, your servant Uriah the Hittite is dead.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The messenger set out, and when he arrived he told David everything Joab had sent him to say.
speaker: Narrator

text: The messenger said to David, ‘The men overpowered us and came out against us in the open, but we drove them back to the entrance of the city gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the archers shot arrows at your servants from the wall, and some of the king’s men died. Moreover, your servant Uriah the Hittite is dead.’
speaker: Narrator

text: David told the messenger, ‘Say this to Joab: “Don’t let this upset you; the sword devours one as well as another. Press the attack against the city and destroy it.” Say this to encourage Joab.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When Uriah’s wife heard that her husband was dead, she mourned for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the time of mourning was over, David had her brought to his house, and she became his wife and bore him a son. But the thing David had done displeased the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord sent Nathan to David. When he came to him, he said, ‘There were two men in a certain town, one rich and the other poor.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rich man had a very large number of sheep and cattle,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the poor man had nothing except one little ewe lamb that he had bought. He raised it, and it grew up with him and his children. It shared his food, drank from his cup and even slept in his arms. It was like a daughter to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Now a traveller came to the rich man, but the rich man refrained from taking one of his own sheep or cattle to prepare a meal for the traveller who had come to him. Instead, he took the ewe lamb that belonged to the poor man and prepared it for the one who had come to him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: David burned with anger against the man and said to Nathan, ‘As surely as the Lord lives, the man who did this must die!
speaker: Narrator

text: He must pay for that lamb four times over, because he did such a thing and had no pity.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Nathan said to David, ‘You are the man! This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: “I anointed you king over Israel, and I delivered you from the hand of Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: I gave your master’s house to you, and your master’s wives into your arms. I gave you all Israel and Judah. And if all this had been too little, I would have given you even more.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why did you despise the word of the Lord by doing what is evil in his eyes? You struck down Uriah the Hittite with the sword and took his wife to be your own. You killed him with the sword of the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, therefore, the sword shall never depart from your house, because you despised me and took the wife of Uriah the Hittite to be your own.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘This is what the Lord says: “Out of your own household I am going to bring calamity on you. Before your very eyes I will take your wives and give them to one who is close to you, and he will sleep with your wives in broad daylight.
speaker: Narrator

text: You did it in secret, but I will do this thing in broad daylight before all Israel.”’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then David said to Nathan, ‘I have sinned against the Lord.’
Nathan replied, ‘The Lord has taken away your sin. You are not going to die.
speaker: Narrator

text: But because by doing this you have shown utter contempt for the Lord, the son born to you will die.’
speaker: Narrator

text: After Nathan had gone home, the Lord struck the child that Uriah’s wife had borne to David, and he became ill.
speaker: Narrator

text: David pleaded with God for the child. He fasted and spent the nights lying in sackcloth on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders of his household stood beside him to get him up from the ground, but he refused, and he would not eat any food with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day the child died. David’s attendants were afraid to tell him that the child was dead, for they thought, ‘While the child was still living, he wouldn’t listen to us when we spoke to him. How can we now tell him the child is dead? He may do something desperate.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
David noticed that his attendants were whispering among themselves, and he realised that the child was dead. ‘Is the child dead?’ he asked.
‘Yes,’ they replied, ‘he is dead.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David got up from the ground. After he had washed, put on lotions and changed his clothes, he went into the house of the Lord and worshipped. Then he went to his own house, and at his request they served him food, and he ate.
speaker: Narrator

text: His attendants asked him, ‘Why are you acting in this way? While the child was alive, you fasted and wept, but now that the child is dead, you get up and eat!’
speaker: Narrator

text: He answered, ‘While the child was still alive, I fasted and wept. I thought, “Who knows? The Lord may be gracious to me and let the child live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But now that he is dead, why should I go on fasting? Can I bring him back again? I will go to him, but he will not return to me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David comforted his wife Bathsheba, and he went to her and made love to her. She gave birth to a son, and they named him Solomon. The Lord loved him;
speaker: Narrator

text: and because the Lord loved him, he sent word through Nathan the prophet to name him Jedidiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile Joab fought against Rabbah of the Ammonites and captured the royal citadel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab then sent messengers to David, saying, ‘I have fought against Rabbah and taken its water supply.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now muster the rest of the troops and besiege the city and capture it. Otherwise I shall take the city, and it will be named after me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So David mustered the entire army and went to Rabbah, and attacked and captured it.
speaker: Narrator

text: David took the crown from their king’s head, and it was placed on his own head. It weighed a talent of gold, and it was set with precious stones. David took a great quantity of plunder from the city
speaker: Narrator

text: and brought out the people who were there, consigning them to labour with saws and with iron picks and axes, and he made them work at brickmaking. David did this to all the Ammonite towns. Then he and his entire army returned to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the course of time, Amnon son of David fell in love with Tamar, the beautiful sister of Absalom son of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Amnon became so obsessed with his sister Tamar that he made himself ill. She was a virgin, and it seemed impossible for him to do anything to her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Amnon had an advisor named Jonadab son of Shimeah, David’s brother. Jonadab was a very shrewd man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He asked Amnon, ‘Why do you, the king’s son, look so haggard morning after morning? Won’t you tell me?’
Amnon said to him, ‘I’m in love with Tamar, my brother Absalom’s sister.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Go to bed and pretend to be ill,’ Jonadab said. ‘When your father comes to see you, say to him, “I would like my sister Tamar to come and give me something to eat. Let her prepare the food in my sight so that I may watch her and then eat it from her hand.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Amnon lay down and pretended to be ill. When the king came to see him, Amnon said to him, ‘I would like my sister Tamar to come and make some special bread in my sight, so that I may eat from her hand.’
speaker: Narrator

text: David sent word to Tamar at the palace: ‘Go to the house of your brother Amnon and prepare some food for him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Tamar went to the house of her brother Amnon, who was lying down. She took some dough, kneaded it, made the bread in his sight and baked it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then she took the pan and served him the bread, but he refused to eat.
‘Send everyone out of here,’ Amnon said. So everyone left him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Amnon said to Tamar, ‘Bring the food here into my bedroom so that I may eat from your hand.’ And Tamar took the bread she had prepared and brought it to her brother Amnon in his bedroom.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when she took it to him to eat, he grabbed her and said, ‘Come to bed with me, my sister.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘No, my brother!’ she said to him. ‘Don’t force me! Such a thing should not be done in Israel! Don’t do this wicked thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: What about me? Where could I get rid of my disgrace? And what about you? You would be like one of the wicked fools in Israel. Please speak to the king; he will not keep me from being married to you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But he refused to listen to her, and since he was stronger than she, he raped her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Amnon hated her with intense hatred. In fact, he hated her more than he had loved her. Amnon said to her, ‘Get up and get out!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘No!’ she said to him. ‘Sending me away would be a greater wrong than what you have already done to me.’
But he refused to listen to her.
speaker: Narrator

text: He called his personal servant and said, ‘Get this woman out of my sight and bolt the door after her.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So his servant put her out and bolted the door after her. She was wearing an ornate robe, for this was the kind of garment the virgin daughters of the king wore.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tamar put ashes on her head and tore the ornate robe she was wearing. She put her hands on her head and went away, weeping aloud as she went.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her brother Absalom said to her, ‘Has that Amnon, your brother, been with you? Be quiet for now, my sister; he is your brother. Don’t take this thing to heart.’ And Tamar lived in her brother Absalom’s house, a desolate woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: When King David heard all this, he was furious.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Absalom never said a word to Amnon, either good or bad; he hated Amnon because he had disgraced his sister Tamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two years later, when Absalom’s sheep-shearers were at Baal Hazor near the border of Ephraim, he invited all the king’s sons to come there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom went to the king and said, ‘Your servant has had shearers come. Will the king and his attendants please join me?’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘No, my son,’ the king replied. ‘All of us should not go; we would only be a burden to you.’ Although Absalom urged him, he still refused to go but gave him his blessing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Absalom said, ‘If not, please let my brother Amnon come with us.’
The king asked him, ‘Why should he go with you?’
speaker: Narrator

text: But Absalom urged him, so he sent with him Amnon and the rest of the king’s sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom ordered his men, ‘Listen! When Amnon is in high spirits from drinking wine and I say to you, “Strike Amnon down,” then kill him. Don’t be afraid. Haven’t I given you this order? Be strong and brave.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Absalom’s men did to Amnon what Absalom had ordered. Then all the king’s sons got up, mounted their mules and fled.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were on their way, the report came to David: ‘Absalom has struck down all the king’s sons; not one of them is left.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king stood up, tore his clothes and lay down on the ground; and all his attendants stood by with their clothes torn.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jonadab son of Shimeah, David’s brother, said, ‘My lord should not think that they killed all the princes; only Amnon is dead. This has been Absalom’s express intention ever since the day that Amnon raped his sister Tamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: My lord the king should not be concerned about the report that all the king’s sons are dead. Only Amnon is dead.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Meanwhile, Absalom had fled.
Now the man standing watch looked up and saw many people on the road west of him, coming down the side of the hill. The watchman went and told the king, ‘I see men in the direction of Horonaim, on the side of the hill.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonadab said to the king, ‘See, the king’s sons have come; it has happened just as your servant said.’
speaker: Narrator

text: As he finished speaking, the king’s sons came in, wailing loudly. The king, too, and all his attendants wept very bitterly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom fled and went to Talmai son of Ammihud, the king of Geshur. But King David mourned many days for his son.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Absalom fled and went to Geshur, he stayed there for three years.
speaker: Narrator

text: And King David longed to go to Absalom, for he was consoled concerning Amnon’s death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab son of Zeruiah knew that the king’s heart longed for Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joab sent someone to Tekoa and had a wise woman brought from there. He said to her, ‘Pretend you are in mourning. Dress in mourning clothes, and don’t use any cosmetic lotions. Act like a woman who has spent many days grieving for the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then go to the king and speak these words to him.’ And Joab put the words in her mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the woman from Tekoa went to the king, she fell with her face to the ground to pay him honour, and she said, ‘Help me, Your Majesty!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king asked her, ‘What is troubling you?’
She said, ‘I am a widow; my husband is dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: I your servant had two sons. They got into a fight with each other in the field, and no one was there to separate them. One struck the other and killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the whole clan has risen up against your servant; they say, “Hand over the one who struck his brother down, so that we may put him to death for the life of his brother whom he killed; then we will get rid of the heir as well.” They would put out the only burning coal I have left, leaving my husband neither name nor descendant on the face of the earth.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to the woman, ‘Go home, and I will issue an order on your behalf.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But the woman from Tekoa said to him, ‘Let my lord the king pardon me and my family, and let the king and his throne be without guilt.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king replied, ‘If anyone says anything to you, bring them to me, and they will not bother you again.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
She said, ‘Then let the king invoke the Lord his God to prevent the avenger of blood from adding to the destruction, so that my son shall not be destroyed.’
‘As surely as the Lord lives,’ he said, ‘not one hair of your son’s head will fall to the ground.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the woman said, ‘Let your servant speak a word to my lord the king.’
‘Speak,’ he replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman said, ‘Why then have you devised a thing like this against the people of God? When the king says this, does he not convict himself, for the king has not brought back his banished son?
speaker: Narrator

text: Like water spilled on the ground, which cannot be recovered, so we must die. But that is not what God desires; rather, he devises ways so that a banished person does not remain banished from him.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘And now I have come to say this to my lord the king because the people have made me afraid. Your servant thought, “I will speak to the king; perhaps he will grant his servant’s request.
speaker: Narrator

text: Perhaps the king will agree to deliver his servant from the hand of the man who is trying to cut off both me and my son from God’s inheritance.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘And now your servant says, “May the word of my lord the king secure my inheritance, for my lord the king is like an angel of God in discerning good and evil. May the Lord your God be with you.”’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the king said to the woman, ‘Don’t keep from me the answer to what I am going to ask you.’
‘Let my lord the king speak,’ the woman said.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king asked, ‘Isn’t the hand of Joab with you in all this?’
The woman answered, ‘As surely as you live, my lord the king, no one can turn to the right or to the left from anything my lord the king says. Yes, it was your servant Joab who instructed me to do this and who put all these words into the mouth of your servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your servant Joab did this to change the present situation. My lord has wisdom like that of an angel of God – he knows everything that happens in the land.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to Joab, ‘Very well, I will do it. Go, bring back the young man Absalom.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab fell with his face to the ground to pay him honour, and he blessed the king. Joab said, ‘Today your servant knows that he has found favour in your eyes, my lord the king, because the king has granted his servant’s request.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joab went to Geshur and brought Absalom back to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king said, ‘He must go to his own house; he must not see my face.’ So Absalom went to his own house and did not see the face of the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: In all Israel there was not a man so highly praised for his handsome appearance as Absalom. From the top of his head to the sole of his foot there was no blemish in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever he cut the hair of his head – he used to cut his hair once a year because it became too heavy for him – he would weigh it, and its weight was two hundred shekels by the royal standard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three sons and a daughter were born to Absalom. His daughter’s name was Tamar, and she became a beautiful woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom lived for two years in Jerusalem without seeing the king’s face.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Absalom sent for Joab in order to send him to the king, but Joab refused to come to him. So he sent a second time, but he refused to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to his servants, ‘Look, Joab’s field is next to mine, and he has barley there. Go and set it on fire.’ So Absalom’s servants set the field on fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joab did go to Absalom’s house, and he said to him, ‘Why have your servants set my field on fire?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom said to Joab, ‘Look, I sent word to you and said, “Come here so that I can send you to the king to ask, ‘Why have I come from Geshur? It would be better for me if I were still there!’” Now then, I want to see the king’s face, and if I am guilty of anything, let him put me to death.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joab went to the king and told him this. Then the king summoned Absalom, and he came in and bowed down with his face to the ground before the king. And the king kissed Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the course of time, Absalom provided himself with a chariot and horses and with fifty men to run ahead of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He would get up early and stand by the side of the road leading to the city gate. Whenever anyone came with a complaint to be placed before the king for a decision, Absalom would call out to him, ‘What town are you from?’ He would answer, ‘Your servant is from one of the tribes of Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Absalom would say to him, ‘Look, your claims are valid and proper, but there is no representative of the king to hear you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And Absalom would add, ‘If only I were appointed judge in the land! Then everyone who has a complaint or case could come to me and I would see that they receive justice.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, whenever anyone approached him to bow down before him, Absalom would reach out his hand, take hold of him and kiss him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom behaved in this way towards all the Israelites who came to the king asking for justice, and so he stole the hearts of the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of four years, Absalom said to the king, ‘Let me go to Hebron and fulfil a vow I made to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: While your servant was living at Geshur in Aram, I made this vow: “If the Lord takes me back to Jerusalem, I will worship the Lord in Hebron.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to him, ‘Go in peace.’ So he went to Hebron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Absalom sent secret messengers throughout the tribes of Israel to say, ‘As soon as you hear the sound of the trumpets, then say, “Absalom is king in Hebron.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: Two hundred men from Jerusalem had accompanied Absalom. They had been invited as guests and went quite innocently, knowing nothing about the matter.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Absalom was offering sacrifices, he also sent for Ahithophel the Gilonite, David’s counsellor, to come from Giloh, his home town. And so the conspiracy gained strength, and Absalom’s following kept on increasing.
speaker: Narrator

text: A messenger came and told David, ‘The hearts of the people of Israel are with Absalom.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said to all his officials who were with him in Jerusalem, ‘Come! We must flee, or none of us will escape from Absalom. We must leave immediately, or he will move quickly to overtake us and bring ruin on us and put the city to the sword.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king’s officials answered him, ‘Your servants are ready to do whatever our lord the king chooses.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king set out, with his entire household following him; but he left ten concubines to take care of the palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king set out, with all the people following him, and they halted at the edge of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: All his men marched past him, along with all the Kerethites and Pelethites; and all the six hundred Gittites who had accompanied him from Gath marched before the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to Ittai the Gittite, ‘Why should you come along with us? Go back and stay with King Absalom. You are a foreigner, an exile from your homeland.
speaker: Narrator

text: You came only yesterday. And today shall I make you wander about with us, when I do not know where I am going? Go back, and take your people with you. May the Lord show you kindness and faithfulness.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But Ittai replied to the king, ‘As surely as the Lord lives, and as my lord the king lives, wherever my lord the king may be, whether it means life or death, there will your servant be.’
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Ittai, ‘Go ahead, march on.’ So Ittai the Gittite marched on with all his men and the families that were with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole countryside wept aloud as all the people passed by. The king also crossed the Kidron Valley, and all the people moved on towards the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zadok was there, too, and all the Levites who were with him were carrying the ark of the covenant of God. They set down the ark of God, and Abiathar offered sacrifices until all the people had finished leaving the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king said to Zadok, ‘Take the ark of God back into the city. If I find favour in the Lord’s eyes, he will bring me back and let me see it and his dwelling-place again.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if he says, “I am not pleased with you,” then I am ready; let him do to me whatever seems good to him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king also said to Zadok the priest, ‘Do you understand? Go back to the city with my blessing. Take your son Ahimaaz with you, and also Abiathar’s son Jonathan. You and Abiathar return with your two sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will wait at the fords in the wilderness until word comes from you to inform me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Zadok and Abiathar took the ark of God back to Jerusalem and stayed there.
speaker: Narrator

text: But David continued up the Mount of Olives, weeping as he went; his head was covered and he was barefoot. All the people with him covered their heads too and were weeping as they went up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now David had been told, ‘Ahithophel is among the conspirators with Absalom.’ So David prayed, ‘Lord, turn Ahithophel’s counsel into foolishness.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When David arrived at the summit, where people used to worship God, Hushai the Arkite was there to meet him, his robe torn and dust on his head.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to him, ‘If you go with me, you will be a burden to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you return to the city and say to Absalom, “Your Majesty, I will be your servant; I was your father’s servant in the past, but now I will be your servant,” then you can help me by frustrating Ahithophel’s advice.
speaker: Narrator

text: Won’t the priests Zadok and Abiathar be there with you? Tell them anything you hear in the king’s palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their two sons, Ahimaaz son of Zadok and Jonathan son of Abiathar, are there with them. Send them to me with anything you hear.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hushai, David’s confidant, arrived at Jerusalem as Absalom was entering the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David had gone a short distance beyond the summit, there was Ziba, the steward of Mephibosheth, waiting to meet him. He had a string of donkeys saddled and loaded with two hundred loaves of bread, a hundred cakes of raisins, a hundred cakes of figs and a skin of wine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king asked Ziba, ‘Why have you brought these?’
Ziba answered, ‘The donkeys are for the king’s household to ride on, the bread and fruit are for the men to eat, and the wine is to refresh those who become exhausted in the wilderness.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king then asked, ‘Where is your master’s grandson?’
Ziba said to him, ‘He is staying in Jerusalem, because he thinks, “Today the Israelites will restore to me my grandfather’s kingdom.”’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the king said to Ziba, ‘All that belonged to Mephibosheth is now yours.’
‘I humbly bow,’ Ziba said. ‘May I find favour in your eyes, my lord the king.’
speaker: Narrator

text: As King David approached Bahurim, a man from the same clan as Saul’s family came out from there. His name was Shimei son of Gera, and he cursed as he came out.
speaker: Narrator

text: He pelted David and all the king’s officials with stones, though all the troops and the special guard were on David’s right and left.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he cursed, Shimei said, ‘Get out, get out, you murderer, you scoundrel!
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord has repaid you for all the blood you shed in the household of Saul, in whose place you have reigned. The Lord has given the kingdom into the hands of your son Absalom. You have come to ruin because you are a murderer!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abishai son of Zeruiah said to the king, ‘Why should this dead dog curse my lord the king? Let me go over and cut off his head.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king said, ‘What does this have to do with you, you sons of Zeruiah? If he is cursing because the Lord said to him, “Curse David,” who can ask, “Why do you do this?”’
speaker: Narrator

text: David then said to Abishai and all his officials, ‘My son, my own flesh and blood, is trying to kill me. How much more, then, this Benjaminite! Leave him alone; let him curse, for the Lord has told him to.
speaker: Narrator

text: It may be that the Lord will look upon my misery and restore to me his covenant blessing instead of his curse today.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So David and his men continued along the road while Shimei was going along the hillside opposite him, cursing as he went and throwing stones at him and showering him with dirt.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king and all the people with him arrived at their destination exhausted. And there he refreshed himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Absalom and all the men of Israel came to Jerusalem, and Ahithophel was with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Hushai the Arkite, David’s confidant, went to Absalom and said to him, ‘Long live the king! Long live the king!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom said to Hushai, ‘So this is the love you show your friend? If he’s your friend, why didn’t you go with him?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Hushai said to Absalom, ‘No, the one chosen by the Lord, by these people and by all the men of Israel – his I will be, and I will remain with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, whom should I serve? Should I not serve the son? Just as I served your father, so I will serve you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom said to Ahithophel, ‘Give us your advice. What should we do?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahithophel answered, ‘Sleep with your father’s concubines whom he left to take care of the palace. Then all Israel will hear that you have made yourself obnoxious to your father, and the hands of everyone with you will be more resolute.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So they pitched a tent for Absalom on the roof, and he slept with his father’s concubines in the sight of all Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now in those days the advice Ahithophel gave was like that of one who enquires of God. That was how both David and Absalom regarded all of Ahithophel’s advice.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahithophel said to Absalom, ‘I would choose twelve thousand men and set out tonight in pursuit of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: I would attack him while he is weary and weak. I would strike him with terror, and then all the people with him will flee. I would strike down only the king
speaker: Narrator

text: and bring all the people back to you. The death of the man you seek will mean the return of all; all the people will be unharmed.’
speaker: Narrator

text: This plan seemed good to Absalom and to all the elders of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Absalom said, ‘Summon also Hushai the Arkite, so that we can hear what he has to say as well.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When Hushai came to him, Absalom said, ‘Ahithophel has given this advice. Should we do what he says? If not, give us your opinion.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Hushai replied to Absalom, ‘The advice Ahithophel has given is not good this time.
speaker: Narrator

text: You know your father and his men; they are fighters, and as fierce as a wild bear robbed of her cubs. Besides, your father is an experienced fighter; he will not spend the night with the troops.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even now, he is hidden in a cave or some other place. If he should attack your troops first, whoever hears about it will say, “There has been a slaughter among the troops who follow Absalom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then even the bravest soldier, whose heart is like the heart of a lion, will melt with fear, for all Israel knows that your father is a fighter and that those with him are brave.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘So I advise you: let all Israel, from Dan to Beersheba – as numerous as the sand on the seashore – be gathered to you, with you yourself leading them into battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then we will attack him wherever he may be found, and we will fall on him as dew settles on the ground. Neither he nor any of his men will be left alive.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he withdraws into a city, then all Israel will bring ropes to that city, and we will drag it down to the valley until not so much as a pebble is left.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom and all the men of Israel said, ‘The advice of Hushai the Arkite is better than that of Ahithophel.’ For the Lord had determined to frustrate the good advice of Ahithophel in order to bring disaster on Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hushai told Zadok and Abiathar, the priests, ‘Ahithophel has advised Absalom and the elders of Israel to do such and such, but I have advised them to do so and so.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now send a message at once and tell David, “Do not spend the night at the fords in the wilderness; cross over without fail, or the king and all the people with him will be swallowed up.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan and Ahimaaz were staying at En Rogel. A female servant was to go and inform them, and they were to go and tell King David, for they could not risk being seen entering the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: But a young man saw them and told Absalom. So the two of them left at once and went to the house of a man in Bahurim. He had a well in his courtyard, and they climbed down into it.
speaker: Narrator

text: His wife took a covering and spread it out over the opening of the well and scattered corn over it. No one knew anything about it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Absalom’s men came to the woman at the house, they asked, ‘Where are Ahimaaz and Jonathan?’
The woman answered them, ‘They crossed over the brook.’ The men searched but found no one, so they returned to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: After they had gone, the two climbed out of the well and went to inform King David. They said to him, ‘Set out and cross the river at once; Ahithophel has advised such and such against you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So David and all the people with him set out and crossed the Jordan. By daybreak, no one was left who had not crossed the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Ahithophel saw that his advice had not been followed, he saddled his donkey and set out for his house in his home town. He put his house in order and then hanged himself. So he died and was buried in his father’s tomb.
speaker: Narrator

text: David went to Mahanaim, and Absalom crossed the Jordan with all the men of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom had appointed Amasa over the army in place of Joab. Amasa was the son of Jether, an Ishmaelite who had married Abigail, the daughter of Nahash and sister of Zeruiah the mother of Joab.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites and Absalom camped in the land of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David came to Mahanaim, Shobi son of Nahash from Rabbah of the Ammonites, and Makir son of Ammiel from Lo Debar, and Barzillai the Gileadite from Rogelim
speaker: Narrator

text: brought bedding and bowls and articles of pottery. They also brought wheat and barley, flour and roasted grain, beans and lentils,
speaker: Narrator

text: honey and curds, sheep, and cheese from cows’ milk for David and his people to eat. For they said, ‘The people have become exhausted and hungry and thirsty in the wilderness.’
speaker: Narrator

text: David mustered the men who were with him and appointed over them commanders of thousands and commanders of hundreds.
speaker: Narrator

text: David sent out his troops, a third under the command of Joab, a third under Joab’s brother Abishai son of Zeruiah, and a third under Ittai the Gittite. The king told the troops, ‘I myself will surely march out with you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But the men said, ‘You must not go out; if we are forced to flee, they won’t care about us. Even if half of us die, they won’t care; but you are worth ten thousand of us. It would be better now for you to give us support from the city.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king answered, ‘I will do whatever seems best to you.’
So the king stood beside the gate while all his men marched out in units of hundreds and of thousands.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king commanded Joab, Abishai and Ittai, ‘Be gentle with the young man Absalom for my sake.’ And all the troops heard the king giving orders concerning Absalom to each of the commanders.
speaker: Narrator

text: David’s army marched out of the city to fight Israel, and the battle took place in the forest of Ephraim.
speaker: Narrator

text: There Israel’s troops were routed by David’s men, and the casualties that day were great – twenty thousand men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The battle spread out over the whole countryside, and the forest swallowed up more men that day than the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Absalom happened to meet David’s men. He was riding his mule, and as the mule went under the thick branches of a large oak, Absalom’s hair got caught in the tree. He was left hanging in mid-air, while the mule he was riding kept on going.
speaker: Narrator

text: When one of the men saw what had happened, he told Joab, ‘I have just seen Absalom hanging in an oak tree.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab said to the man who had told him this, ‘What! You saw him? Why didn’t you strike him to the ground right there? Then I would have had to give you ten shekels of silver and a warrior’s belt.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But the man replied, ‘Even if a thousand shekels were weighed out into my hands, I would not lay a hand on the king’s son. In our hearing the king commanded you and Abishai and Ittai, “Protect the young man Absalom for my sake.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And if I had put my life in jeopardy – and nothing is hidden from the king – you would have kept your distance from me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab said, ‘I am not going to wait like this for you.’ So he took three javelins in his hand and plunged them into Absalom’s heart while Absalom was still alive in the oak tree.
speaker: Narrator
