text: And ten of Joab’s armour-bearers surrounded Absalom, struck him and killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joab sounded the trumpet, and the troops stopped pursuing Israel, for Joab halted them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took Absalom, threw him into a big pit in the forest and piled up a large heap of rocks over him. Meanwhile, all the Israelites fled to their homes.
speaker: Narrator

text: During his life-time Absalom had taken a pillar and erected it in the King’s Valley as a monument to himself, for he thought, ‘I have no son to carry on the memory of my name.’ He named the pillar after himself, and it is called Absalom’s Monument to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Ahimaaz son of Zadok said, ‘Let me run and take the news to the king that the Lord has vindicated him by delivering him from the hand of his enemies.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You are not the one to take the news today,’ Joab told him. ‘You may take the news another time, but you must not do so today, because the king’s son is dead.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joab said to a Cushite, ‘Go, tell the king what you have seen.’ The Cushite bowed down before Joab and ran off.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ahimaaz son of Zadok again said to Joab, ‘Come what may, please let me run behind the Cushite.’
But Joab replied, ‘My son, why do you want to go? You don’t have any news that will bring you a reward.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said, ‘Come what may, I want to run.’
So Joab said, ‘Run!’ Then Ahimaaz ran by way of the plain and outran the Cushite.
speaker: Narrator

text: While David was sitting between the inner and outer gates, the watchman went up to the roof of the gateway by the wall. As he looked out, he saw a man running alone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The watchman called out to the king and reported it.
The king said, ‘If he is alone, he must have good news.’ And the runner came closer and closer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the watchman saw another runner, and he called down to the gatekeeper, ‘Look, another man running alone!’
The king said, ‘He must be bringing good news, too.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
The watchman said, ‘It seems to me that the first one runs like Ahimaaz son of Zadok.’
‘He’s a good man,’ the king said. ‘He comes with good news.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ahimaaz called out to the king, ‘All is well!’ He bowed down before the king with his face to the ground and said, ‘Praise be to the Lord your God! He has delivered up those who lifted their hands against my lord the king.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king asked, ‘Is the young man Absalom safe?’
Ahimaaz answered, ‘I saw great confusion just as Joab was about to send the king’s servant and me, your servant, but I don’t know what it was.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said, ‘Stand aside and wait here.’ So he stepped aside and stood there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Cushite arrived and said, ‘My lord the king, hear the good news! The Lord has vindicated you today by delivering you from the hand of all who rose up against you.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king asked the Cushite, ‘Is the young man Absalom safe?’
The Cushite replied, ‘May the enemies of my lord the king and all who rise up to harm you be like that young man.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king was shaken. He went up to the room over the gateway and wept. As he went, he said: ‘O my son Absalom! My son, my son Absalom! If only I had died instead of you – O Absalom, my son, my son!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab was told, ‘The king is weeping and mourning for Absalom.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And for the whole army the victory that day was turned into mourning, because on that day the troops heard it said, ‘The king is grieving for his son.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The men stole into the city that day as men steal in who are ashamed when they flee from battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king covered his face and cried aloud, ‘O my son Absalom! O Absalom, my son, my son!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joab went into the house to the king and said, ‘Today you have humiliated all your men, who have just saved your life and the lives of your sons and daughters and the lives of your wives and concubines.
speaker: Narrator

text: You love those who hate you and hate those who love you. You have made it clear today that the commanders and their men mean nothing to you. I see that you would be pleased if Absalom were alive today and all of us were dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now go out and encourage your men. I swear by the Lord that if you don’t go out, not a man will be left with you by nightfall. This will be worse for you than all the calamities that have come on you from your youth till now.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the king got up and took his seat in the gateway. When the men were told, ‘The king is sitting in the gateway,’ they all came before him.
Meanwhile, the Israelites had fled to their homes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Throughout the tribes of Israel, all the people were arguing among themselves, saying, ‘The king delivered us from the hand of our enemies; he is the one who rescued us from the hand of the Philistines. But now he has fled the country to escape from Absalom;
speaker: Narrator

text: and Absalom, whom we anointed to rule over us, has died in battle. So why do you say nothing about bringing the king back?’
speaker: Narrator

text: King David sent this message to Zadok and Abiathar, the priests: ‘Ask the elders of Judah, “Why should you be the last to bring the king back to his palace, since what is being said throughout Israel has reached the king at his quarters?
speaker: Narrator

text: You are my relatives, my own flesh and blood. So why should you be the last to bring back the king?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And say to Amasa, “Are you not my own flesh and blood? May God deal with me, be it ever so severely, if you are not the commander of my army for life in place of Joab.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: He won over the hearts of the men of Judah so that they were all of one mind. They sent word to the king, ‘Return, you and all your men.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the king returned and went as far as the Jordan.
Now the men of Judah had come to Gilgal to go out and meet the king and bring him across the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shimei son of Gera, the Benjaminite from Bahurim, hurried down with the men of Judah to meet King David.
speaker: Narrator

text: With him were a thousand Benjaminites, along with Ziba, the steward of Saul’s household, and his fifteen sons and twenty servants. They rushed to the Jordan, where the king was.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They crossed at the ford to take the king’s household over and to do whatever he wished.
When Shimei son of Gera crossed the Jordan, he fell prostrate before the king
speaker: Narrator

text: and said to him, ‘May my lord not hold me guilty. Do not remember how your servant did wrong on the day my lord the king left Jerusalem. May the king put it out of his mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I your servant know that I have sinned, but today I have come here as the first from the tribes of Joseph to come down and meet my lord the king.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abishai son of Zeruiah said, ‘Shouldn’t Shimei be put to death for this? He cursed the Lord’s anointed.’
speaker: Narrator

text: David replied, ‘What does this have to do with you, you sons of Zeruiah? What right do you have to interfere? Should anyone be put to death in Israel today? Don’t I know that today I am king over Israel?’
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king said to Shimei, ‘You shall not die.’ And the king promised him on oath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mephibosheth, Saul’s grandson, also went down to meet the king. He had not taken care of his feet or trimmed his moustache or washed his clothes from the day the king left until the day he returned safely.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he came from Jerusalem to meet the king, the king asked him, ‘Why didn’t you go with me, Mephibosheth?’
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, ‘My lord the king, since I your servant am lame, I said, “I will have my donkey saddled and will ride on it, so that I can go with the king.” But Ziba my servant betrayed me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he has slandered your servant to my lord the king. My lord the king is like an angel of God; so do whatever you wish.
speaker: Narrator

text: All my grandfather’s descendants deserved nothing but death from my lord the king, but you gave your servant a place among those who eat at your table. So what right do I have to make any more appeals to the king?’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to him, ‘Why say more? I order you and Ziba to divide the land.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Mephibosheth said to the king, ‘Let him take everything, now that my lord the king has returned home safely.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Barzillai the Gileadite also came down from Rogelim to cross the Jordan with the king and to send him on his way from there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Barzillai was very old, eighty years of age. He had provided for the king during his stay in Mahanaim, for he was a very wealthy man.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to Barzillai, ‘Cross over with me and stay with me in Jerusalem, and I will provide for you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But Barzillai answered the king, ‘How many more years shall I live, that I should go up to Jerusalem with the king?
speaker: Narrator

text: I am now eighty years old. Can I tell the difference between what is enjoyable and what is not? Can your servant taste what he eats and drinks? Can I still hear the voices of male and female singers? Why should your servant be an added burden to my lord the king?
speaker: Narrator

text: Your servant will cross over the Jordan with the king for a short distance, but why should the king reward me in this way?
speaker: Narrator

text: Let your servant return, that I may die in my own town near the tomb of my father and mother. But here is your servant Kimham. Let him cross over with my lord the king. Do for him whatever you wish.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said, ‘Kimham shall cross over with me, and I will do for him whatever you wish. And anything you desire from me I will do for you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the people crossed the Jordan, and then the king crossed over. The king kissed Barzillai and bade him farewell, and Barzillai returned to his home.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king crossed over to Gilgal, Kimham crossed with him. All the troops of Judah and half the troops of Israel had taken the king over.
speaker: Narrator

text: Soon all the men of Israel were coming to the king and saying to him, ‘Why did our brothers, the men of Judah, steal the king away and bring him and his household across the Jordan, together with all his men?’
speaker: Narrator

text: All the men of Judah answered the men of Israel, ‘We did this because the king is closely related to us. Why are you angry about it? Have we eaten any of the king’s provisions? Have we taken anything for ourselves?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the men of Israel answered the men of Judah, ‘We have ten shares in the king; so we have a greater claim on David than you have. Why then do you treat us with contempt? Weren’t we the first to speak of bringing back our king?’
But the men of Judah pressed their claims even more forcefully than the men of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now a troublemaker named Sheba son of Bikri, a Benjaminite, happened to be there. He sounded the trumpet and shouted,
‘We have no share in David,
    no part in Jesse’s son!
Every man to his tent, Israel!’
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the men of Israel deserted David to follow Sheba son of Bikri. But the men of Judah stayed by their king all the way from the Jordan to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David returned to his palace in Jerusalem, he took the ten concubines he had left to take care of the palace and put them in a house under guard. He provided for them but had no sexual relations with them. They were kept in confinement till the day of their death, living as widows.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king said to Amasa, ‘Summon the men of Judah to come to me within three days, and be here yourself.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Amasa went to summon Judah, he took longer than the time the king had set for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Abishai, ‘Now Sheba son of Bikri will do us more harm than Absalom did. Take your master’s men and pursue him, or he will find fortified cities and escape from us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joab’s men and the Kerethites and Pelethites and all the mighty warriors went out under the command of Abishai. They marched out from Jerusalem to pursue Sheba son of Bikri.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were at the great rock in Gibeon, Amasa came to meet them. Joab was wearing his military tunic, and strapped over it at his waist was a belt with a dagger in its sheath. As he stepped forward, it dropped out of its sheath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab said to Amasa, ‘How are you, my brother?’ Then Joab took Amasa by the beard with his right hand to kiss him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Amasa was not on his guard against the dagger in Joab’s hand, and Joab plunged it into his belly, and his intestines spilled out on the ground. Without being stabbed again, Amasa died. Then Joab and his brother Abishai pursued Sheba son of Bikri.
speaker: Narrator

text: One of Joab’s men stood beside Amasa and said, ‘Whoever favours Joab, and whoever is for David, let him follow Joab!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Amasa lay wallowing in his blood in the middle of the road, and the man saw that all the troops came to a halt there. When he realised that everyone who came up to Amasa stopped, he dragged him from the road into a field and threw a garment over him.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Amasa had been removed from the road, everyone went on with Joab to pursue Sheba son of Bikri.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sheba passed through all the tribes of Israel to Abel Beth Maakah and through the entire region of the Bikrites, who gathered together and followed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the troops with Joab came and besieged Sheba in Abel Beth Maakah. They built a siege ramp up to the city, and it stood against the outer fortifications. While they were battering the wall to bring it down,
speaker: Narrator

text: a wise woman called from the city, ‘Listen! Listen! Tell Joab to come here so that I can speak to him.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
He went towards her, and she asked, ‘Are you Joab?’
‘I am,’ he answered.
She said, ‘Listen to what your servant has to say.’
‘I’m listening,’ he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: She continued, ‘Long ago they used to say, “Get your answer at Abel,” and that settled it.
speaker: Narrator

text: We are the peaceful and faithful in Israel. You are trying to destroy a city that is a mother in Israel. Why do you want to swallow up the Lord’s inheritance?’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Far be it from me!’ Joab replied, ‘Far be it from me to swallow up or destroy!
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is not the case. A man named Sheba son of Bikri, from the hill country of Ephraim, has lifted up his hand against the king, against David. Hand over this one man, and I’ll withdraw from the city.’
The woman said to Joab, ‘His head will be thrown to you from the wall.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the woman went to all the people with her wise advice, and they cut off the head of Sheba son of Bikri and threw it to Joab. So he sounded the trumpet, and his men dispersed from the city, each returning to his home. And Joab went back to the king in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab was over Israel’s entire army; Benaiah son of Jehoiada was over the Kerethites and Pelethites;
speaker: Narrator

text: Adoniram was in charge of forced labour; Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was recorder;
speaker: Narrator

text: Sheva was secretary; Zadok and Abiathar were priests;
speaker: Narrator

text: and Ira the Jairite was David’s priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: During the reign of David, there was a famine for three successive years; so David sought the face of the Lord. The Lord said, ‘It is on account of Saul and his blood-stained house; it is because he put the Gibeonites to death.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king summoned the Gibeonites and spoke to them. (Now the Gibeonites were not a part of Israel but were survivors of the Amorites; the Israelites had sworn to spare them, but Saul in his zeal for Israel and Judah had tried to annihilate them.)
speaker: Narrator

text: David asked the Gibeonites, ‘What shall I do for you? How shall I make atonement so that you will bless the Lord’s inheritance?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Gibeonites answered him, ‘We have no right to demand silver or gold from Saul or his family, nor do we have the right to put anyone in Israel to death.’
‘What do you want me to do for you?’ David asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: They answered the king, ‘As for the man who destroyed us and plotted against us so that we have been decimated and have no place anywhere in Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text:
let seven of his male descendants be given to us to be killed and their bodies exposed before the Lord at Gibeah of Saul – the Lord’s chosen one.’
So the king said, ‘I will give them to you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king spared Mephibosheth son of Jonathan, the son of Saul, because of the oath before the Lord between David and Jonathan son of Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king took Armoni and Mephibosheth, the two sons of Aiah’s daughter Rizpah, whom she had borne to Saul, together with the five sons of Saul’s daughter Merab, whom she had borne to Adriel son of Barzillai the Meholathite.
speaker: Narrator

text: He handed them over to the Gibeonites, who killed them and exposed their bodies on a hill before the Lord. All seven of them fell together; they were put to death during the first days of harvest, just as the barley harvest was beginning.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rizpah daughter of Aiah took sackcloth and spread it out for herself on a rock. From the beginning of the harvest till the rain poured down from the heavens on the bodies, she did not let the birds touch them by day or the wild animals by night.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David was told what Aiah’s daughter Rizpah, Saul’s concubine, had done,
speaker: Narrator

text: he went and took the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan from the citizens of Jabesh Gilead. (They had stolen their bodies from the public square at Beth Shan, where the Philistines had hung them after they struck Saul down on Gilboa.)
speaker: Narrator

text: David brought the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan from there, and the bones of those who had been killed and exposed were gathered up.
speaker: Narrator

text: They buried the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan in the tomb of Saul’s father Kish, at Zela in Benjamin, and did everything the king commanded. After that, God answered prayer on behalf of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once again there was a battle between the Philistines and Israel. David went down with his men to fight against the Philistines, and he became exhausted.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Ishbi-Benob, one of the descendants of Rapha, whose bronze spearhead weighed three hundred shekels and who was armed with a new sword, said he would kill David.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Abishai son of Zeruiah came to David’s rescue; he struck the Philistine down and killed him. Then David’s men swore to him, saying, ‘Never again will you go out with us to battle, so that the lamp of Israel will not be extinguished.’
speaker: Narrator

text: In the course of time, there was another battle with the Philistines, at Gob. At that time Sibbekai the Hushathite killed Saph, one of the descendants of Rapha.
speaker: Narrator

text: In another battle with the Philistines at Gob, Elhanan son of Jair the Bethlehemite killed the brother of Goliath the Gittite, who had a spear with a shaft like a weaver’s rod.
speaker: Narrator

text: In still another battle, which took place at Gath, there was a huge man with six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot – twenty-four in all. He also was descended from Rapha.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he taunted Israel, Jonathan son of Shimeah, David’s brother, killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: These four were descendants of Rapha in Gath, and they fell at the hands of David and his men.
speaker: Narrator

text: David sang to the Lord the words of this song when the Lord delivered him from the hand of all his enemies and from the hand of Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said:
‘The Lord is my rock, my fortress and my deliverer;
speaker: Narrator

text:
my God is my rock, in whom I take refuge,
    my shield and the horn of my salvation.
He is my stronghold, my refuge and my saviour –
    from violent people you save me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘I called to the Lord, who is worthy of praise,
    and have been saved from my enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The waves of death swirled about me;
    the torrents of destruction overwhelmed me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The cords of the grave coiled around me;
    the snares of death confronted me.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
He parted the heavens and came down;
    dark clouds were under his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He mounted the cherubim and flew;
    he soared on the wings of the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He made darkness his canopy around him –
    the dark rain clouds of the sky.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Out of the brightness of his presence
    bolts of lightning blazed forth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord thundered from heaven;
    the voice of the Most High resounded.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shot his arrows and scattered the enemy,
    with great bolts of lightning he routed them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The valleys of the sea were exposed
    and the foundations of the earth laid bare
at the rebuke of the Lord,
    at the blast of breath from his nostrils.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘He reached down from on high and took hold of me;
    he drew me out of deep waters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He rescued me from my powerful enemy,
    from my foes, who were too strong for me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They confronted me in the day of my disaster,
    but the Lord was my support.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He brought me out into a spacious place;
    he rescued me because he delighted in me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘The Lord has dealt with me according to my righteousness;
    according to the cleanness of my hands he has rewarded me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I have kept the ways of the Lord;
    I am not guilty of turning from my God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All his laws are before me;
    I have not turned away from his decrees.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have been blameless before him
    and have kept myself from sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord has rewarded me according to my righteousness,
    according to my cleanness in his sight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘To the faithful you show yourself faithful,
    to the blameless you show yourself blameless,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to the pure you show yourself pure,
    but to the devious you show yourself shrewd.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You save the humble,
    but your eyes are on the haughty to bring them low.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You, Lord, are my lamp;
    the Lord turns my darkness into light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With your help I can advance against a troop;
    with my God I can scale a wall.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For who is God besides the Lord?
    And who is the Rock except our God?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is God who arms me with strength
    and keeps my way secure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He makes my feet like the feet of a deer;
    he causes me to stand on the heights.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He trains my hands for battle;
    my arms can bend a bow of bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You make your saving help my shield;
    your help has made me great.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You provide a broad path for my feet,
    so that my ankles do not give way.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘I pursued my enemies and crushed them;
    I did not turn back till they were destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I crushed them completely, and they could not rise;
    they fell beneath my feet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You armed me with strength for battle;
    you humbled my adversaries before me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You made my enemies turn their backs in flight,
    and I destroyed my foes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They cried for help, but there was no one to save them –
    to the Lord, but he did not answer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I beat them as fine as the dust of the earth;
    I pounded and trampled them like mud in the streets.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
foreigners cower before me;
    as soon as they hear of me, they obey me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They all lose heart;
    they come trembling from their strongholds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘The Lord lives! Praise be to my Rock!
    Exalted be my God, the Rock, my Saviour!
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is the God who avenges me,
    who puts the nations under me,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Therefore I will praise you, Lord, among the nations;
    I will sing the praises of your name.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
These are the last words of David:
‘The inspired utterance of David son of Jesse,
    the utterance of the man exalted by the Most High,
the man anointed by the God of Jacob,
    the hero of Israel’s songs:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘The Spirit of the Lord spoke through me;
    his word was on my tongue.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The God of Israel spoke,
    the Rock of Israel said to me:
“When one rules over people in righteousness,
    when he rules in the fear of God,
speaker: Narrator

text:
he is like the light of morning at sunrise
    on a cloudless morning,
like the brightness after rain
    that brings grass from the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘If my house were not right with God,
    surely he would not have made with me an everlasting covenant,
    arranged and secured in every part;
surely he would not bring to fruition my salvation
    and grant me my every desire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But evil men are all to be cast aside like thorns,
    which are not gathered with the hand.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
These are the names of David’s mighty warriors:
Josheb-Basshebeth, a Tahkemonite, was chief of the Three; he raised his spear against eight hundred men, whom he killed in one encounter.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next to him was Eleazar son of Dodai the Ahohite. As one of the three mighty warriors, he was with David when they taunted the Philistines gathered at Pas Dammim for battle. Then the Israelites retreated,
speaker: Narrator

text: but Eleazar stood his ground and struck down the Philistines till his hand grew tired and froze to the sword. The Lord brought about a great victory that day. The troops returned to Eleazar, but only to strip the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next to him was Shammah son of Agee the Hararite. When the Philistines banded together at a place where there was a field full of lentils, Israel’s troops fled from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Shammah took his stand in the middle of the field. He defended it and struck the Philistines down, and the Lord brought about a great victory.
speaker: Narrator

text: During harvest time, three of the thirty chief warriors came down to David at the cave of Adullam, while a band of Philistines was encamped in the Valley of Rephaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time David was in the stronghold, and the Philistine garrison was at Bethlehem.
speaker: Narrator

text: David longed for water and said, ‘Oh, that someone would get me a drink of water from the well near the gate of Bethlehem!’
speaker: Narrator

text: So the three mighty warriors broke through the Philistine lines, drew water from the well near the gate of Bethlehem and carried it back to David. But he refused to drink it; instead, he poured it out before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Far be it from me, Lord, to do this!’ he said. ‘Is it not the blood of men who went at the risk of their lives?’ And David would not drink it.
Such were the exploits of the three mighty warriors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abishai the brother of Joab son of Zeruiah was chief of the Three. He raised his spear against three hundred men, whom he killed, and so he became as famous as the Three.
speaker: Narrator

text: Was he not held in greater honour than the Three? He became their commander, even though he was not included among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Benaiah son of Jehoiada, a valiant fighter from Kabzeel, performed great exploits. He struck down Moab’s two mightiest warriors. He also went down into a pit on a snowy day and killed a lion.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he struck down a huge Egyptian. Although the Egyptian had a spear in his hand, Benaiah went against him with a club. He snatched the spear from the Egyptian’s hand and killed him with his own spear.
speaker: Narrator

text: Such were the exploits of Benaiah son of Jehoiada; he too was as famous as the three mighty warriors.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was held in greater honour than any of the Thirty, but he was not included among the Three. And David put him in charge of his bodyguard.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Among the Thirty were:
Asahel the brother of Joab,
Elhanan son of Dodo from Bethlehem,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shammah the Harodite,
Elika the Harodite,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Helez the Paltite,
Ira son of Ikkesh from Tekoa,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Abiezer from Anathoth,
Sibbekai the Hushathite,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Zalmon the Ahohite,
Maharai the Netophathite,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Heled son of Baanah the Netophathite,
Ithai son of Ribai from Gibeah in Benjamin,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Benaiah the Pirathonite,
Hiddai from the ravines of Gaash,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Abi-Albon the Arbathite,
Azmaveth the Barhumite,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Eliahba the Shaalbonite,
the sons of Jashen,
Jonathan
speaker: Narrator

text:
son of Shammah the Hararite,
Ahiam son of Sharar the Hararite,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Eliphelet son of Ahasbai the Maakathite,
Eliam son of Ahithophel the Gilonite,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hezro the Carmelite,
Paarai the Arbite,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Igal son of Nathan from Zobah,
the son of Hagri,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Zelek the Ammonite,
Naharai the Beerothite, the armour-bearer of Joab son of Zeruiah,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ira the Ithrite,
Gareb the Ithrite
speaker: Narrator

text:
and Uriah the Hittite.
There were thirty-seven in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again the anger of the Lord burned against Israel, and he incited David against them, saying, ‘Go and take a census of Israel and Judah.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king said to Joab and the army commanders with him, ‘Go throughout the tribes of Israel from Dan to Beersheba and enrol the fighting men, so that I may know how many there are.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joab replied to the king, ‘May the Lord your God multiply the troops a hundred times over, and may the eyes of my lord the king see it. But why does my lord the king want to do such a thing?’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king’s word, however, overruled Joab and the army commanders; so they left the presence of the king to enrol the fighting men of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: After crossing the Jordan, they camped near Aroer, south of the town in the gorge, and then went through Gad and on to Jazer.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went to Gilead and the region of Tahtim Hodshi, and on to Dan Jaan and around towards Sidon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they went towards the fortress of Tyre and all the towns of the Hivites and Canaanites. Finally, they went on to Beersheba in the Negev of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: After they had gone through the entire land, they came back to Jerusalem at the end of nine months and twenty days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab reported the number of the fighting men to the king: in Israel there were eight hundred thousand able-bodied men who could handle a sword, and in Judah five hundred thousand.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was conscience-stricken after he had counted the fighting men, and he said to the Lord, ‘I have sinned greatly in what I have done. Now, Lord, I beg you, take away the guilt of your servant. I have done a very foolish thing.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Before David got up the next morning, the word of the Lord had come to Gad the prophet, David’s seer:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Go and tell David, “This is what the Lord says: I am giving you three options. Choose one of them for me to carry out against you.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gad went to David and said to him, ‘Shall there come on you three years of famine in your land? Or three months of fleeing from your enemies while they pursue you? Or three days of plague in your land? Now then, think it over and decide how I should answer the one who sent me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Gad, ‘I am in deep distress. Let us fall into the hands of the Lord, for his mercy is great; but do not let me fall into human hands.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord sent a plague on Israel from that morning until the end of the time designated, and seventy thousand of the people from Dan to Beersheba died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the angel stretched out his hand to destroy Jerusalem, the Lord relented concerning the disaster and said to the angel who was afflicting the people, ‘Enough! Withdraw your hand.’ The angel of the Lord was then at the threshing-floor of Araunah the Jebusite.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David saw the angel who was striking down the people, he said to the Lord, ‘I have sinned; I, the shepherd, have done wrong. These are but sheep. What have they done? Let your hand fall on me and my family.’
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day Gad went to David and said to him, ‘Go up and build an altar to the Lord on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So David went up, as the Lord had commanded through Gad.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Araunah looked and saw the king and his officials coming towards him, he went out and bowed down before the king with his face to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Araunah said, ‘Why has my lord the king come to his servant?’
‘To buy your threshing-floor,’ David answered, ‘so that I can build an altar to the Lord, that the plague on the people may be stopped.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Araunah said to David, ‘Let my lord the king take whatever he wishes and offer it up. Here are oxen for the burnt offering, and here are threshing-sledges and ox yokes for the wood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your Majesty, Araunah gives all this to the king.’ Araunah also said to him, ‘May the Lord your God accept you.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the king replied to Araunah, ‘No, I insist on paying you for it. I will not sacrifice to the Lord my God burnt offerings that cost me nothing.’
So David bought the threshing-floor and the oxen and paid fifty shekels of silver for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: David built an altar to the Lord there and sacrificed burnt offerings and fellowship offerings. Then the Lord answered his prayer on behalf of the land, and the plague on Israel was stopped.
speaker: Narrator
